ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about the (Neo-)Gricean approach to pragmatics, scalar implicature, and more, as well as Rational Speech Act Theory. Topics in experimental pragmatics.
Deep and specific instruction in implicature, especially within current work on lying

I learned a lot about the "unsaid" parts of language; the mechanisms behind implications and the reason we word things in the way we do, connotations, and the language used to describe these differences in meaning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was mostly in a lecture format and it would have been nice to have more discussion. But I did like the breadth of what we covered.

This is the best course I've taken while at Yale. Professor Horn is one of the best, if not the best, instructor I've had. This class is the perfect example of a class that is taught so well that you don't need to have an insane amount of work to still learn a lot.

The readings for this course are excellent and well chosen. 
Sometimes when engagement was low in course, it was hard to get through the really long course

I really can't think of any weaknesses. Prof. Horn is amazing and I felt very engaged during the class. I appreciated the type of group learning we did, with giving presentations and having regular discussion board conversations.
Strengths: you get to cover a lot of interesting material with a very knowledgeable and engaging professor. I wish there had been more time in the course! Weaknesses: none.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yeah! If you like pragmatics this will be the best class you ever take.
Absolutely! If you get to take any chance with Professor Horn, do it. You won't regret it.
Yes, if you know what it's about going in
Yes, it was very interesting and fun!

Absolutely! I had a lot of fun, and I'd recommend it to anyone with even a mild interest in pragmatics or philosophy. It's the kind of class anyone (not just those majoring in phil/ling) can benefit from, because it gives a lot of background for how we use language.

Yes! If you are interested in linguistics, philosophy, or just think the course description sounds cool, I would definitely recommend this course, especially for the chance to learn from Professor Horn.
